content.description: The first half of this route is a nice finger/hand crack with good pro. The second half is a loose & gravely 5.1.
content.protection: Easily protected lead with medium cams. There are rap slings w/ rings on top.
content.location: Wilma Rubble is on Lower Freeway Wall. It is immediately right of the large roof in the middle of the wall.

climbs.name: Thigh Master (aka Rolling Rock)
climbs.fa: (TR) Todd Swain, November, 1991, FL: Tucker Tech, Todd Gordon and Tom Burke, December 1999

content.description: Climb a fun, awkward start (face, stem) to a thin crack (right hand) below the first bolt.  Protect the crack, then step up and clip the first bolt.  Try to resist the A0 moves that follow.  Get established in the shallow face bowl leading to the second bolt, clip that rig, then up.  Fun!
content.protection:
Standard rack. Two bolts (1/2 inch S.S.).

I found a 00 TCU, a #2 TCU, a couple 1/2" cams, a small nut and a #1 Camalot particularly useful.

Bolts replaced 2021
content.location: Right of Smooth As Silk, on South facing narrow buttress with two visible bolt anchors on a shallow concave face.  Faces the road.  Kind of at the last transition of the crag from SE to the SW end.  Rappel from same sling nest anchor as Smooth As Silk.

content.description: Fun stemming up an overhanging corner (crux) leads to a wide crack above
content.protection: bring two 4 inch pieces plus some smaller gear
content.location: This route is near the north end of the west face, where the wall is much shorter than by Freeway.

content.description: a good quality wide hands crack
content.location: This route is not far from the north end of the west face.  It starts near the ground and climbs an obvious crack to a broken area.

climbs.name: Start Trundling
climbs.fa: Darryl Nakahira, Randy Vogel, and Maria Cranor, 1980

content.description: a short finger jam crux leads to easier hand jamming above
content.location: This is near the north end of the west face, to the right of Stop Trundling.

content.description:
Smooth as Silk can be divided into two distinct sections. The lower section involves bouldery moves off the ground to a short hand traverse before easing off into a lower angle slab. The upper section ascends a splitter finger crack up a very smooth, relatively low angle slab. A small scoop at the base of this second section complicates getting onto the slab and provides the crux of the route.

Smooth as Silk is located around the corner from the Freeway Wall, on the end of the buttress that faces the road. The upper slab is plainly visible from the car as you approach the parking area on the Lost Horse Road. A short boulder scramble gets you to the base.
content.protection: Thin rack to #2 Camalot (even that may be bigger than you'll need). This climb sews up beautifully with nuts and TCUs.

content.description:
Start at the base of the chimney as for the reasonable start to

Smooth as Silk

. Climb the chimney about 15 feet, then climb an obvious crack in a shallow right-facing corner. At the top of the corner, go up and left (as for the

Rolling Rock

) to the

Smooth as Silk

anchor.

Rap with a 50m or longer rope from the communal anchor.
content.protection: Carry gear to a gold Camalot and a couple shoulder length slings.
content.location:
Start at the base of the chimney as for the reasonable start to

Smooth as Silk

.
on the north end of the formation, and to the left of Smooth As Silk

content.description: Planetary Motion starts in a short, steep hand crack, goes up a low angle, knobby slab and then snakes right, then left, around a bulging headwall to finish on a high thin crack.
content.protection: light trad rack; runout at top
content.location:
This route is on the far left corner of the NW buttress of Freeway Wall. Both the lower wide crack and the upper thin crack are clearly visible from the Lost Horse dirt road.

Park at the turnout just north of the buttress.

content.description: This is a long, non-sustained crack and face
content.location: at the extreme north end of the formation, 100 feet left of Smooth As Silk.

content.description: This is an enjoyable, easy climb about 30' right of False Smooth as Silk.
content.location: The route starts at a flake, just right and below the highest tree at the base of the buttress. Climb up to the ledge that the tree is on, and then into a wide off-width crack.

content.description:
Start at the base of the

Stop Trundling

corner. Climb the left-slanting, overhanging finger crack up the wall just left of the corner. Above, go up and left to the

Smooth as Silk

anchor or join

Stop Trundling

to the top.
content.protection: Carry multiple TCUs and wires for the finger crack and gear to a blue Camalot above.
content.location:
Start at the base of the

Stop Trundling

corner.

content.description:
Start just down and left of the base of the

Start Trundling

corner.

Climb the short, varnished face with one bolt just left of the

Falling Rock

finger crack.
content.location:
Start just down and left of the base of the

Start Trundling

corner. This spot is just up and right of the start of

Rolling Rock

.
